awd_titl_txt: LTREB Renewal: Multiscale effects of climate variability and change on hydrologic regimes, ecosystem function, and community structure in a desert stream and its catchment
awd_abstract_narration:
River and wetland ecosystems provide important ecosystem services that are determined by climate, such as water for human uses and habitat support for fish and wildlife.  In southwestern deserts of the United States, years of extreme drought often follow years of very wet conditions, thus it is impossible to define river ecosystem services in terms of average conditions. In fact, high variability is an apt descriptor of the hydrologic regimes for streams in this region. In this project, researchers are using new statistical techniques that describe hydrological regimes, coupled with long-term measurements of stream structure and processes, to understand how shifts in climate and river discharge regimes on many time scales will influence the ecosystem. The research will focus on factors that explain why the abundance and distribution of wetland plants and the degree of nitrogen limitation vary dramatically among years. Also, the variation among years in patterns of change after spring floods - in primary production, nutrient retention, and community composition (of invertebrates and plants)- will be related to within- and among-year variation in hydrology, to determine the impact of regimes on these successional patterns. Finally, an interdisciplinary team of collaborators will reevaluate stream ecosystem models and test new models using long-term data from this and other desert streams. 

This research will advance synthesis of long-term data from desert streams and advance understanding in ways that can contribute to the general theory of stability of multiple ecosystem states. A graduate student-led workshop will give students experience in using long-term databases and foster collaborative interactions. Activities of a collaboratory will expand the coupling of innovative hydrologic time-series analyses with ecological data. The database for this well-known stream ecosystem will be extended to more than 40 years and made available to the scientific and management community, potentially informing management in a highly variable environment where stressors of climate change and population growth are converging.

por.por_cntn:
In southwestern deserts of the United States, years of extreme drought can follow years of very wet conditions, thus it is challenging to define any sort of average conditions. In fact, high variability is an apt descriptor of the hydrological regimes for streams in this region (photos 1 and 2). In this project, researchers used new statistical techniques that describe hydrological regimes, coupled with long-term measurements of stream structure and processes, to understand how shifts in these regimes on many time scales influence the ecosystem. 

Intellectual Merit: Researchers showed how the abundance and distribution of wetland plants along 12 km of the stream varied among years in species-specific ways according to their response to regimes of flood and drought (photos 3 and 4). Further, they found that the geomorphic templat--established to some extent by the shifts in sediment distribution during flood--was a consistent predictor of nutrient hotspots and the presence of wetland plant patches. Variation among years in patterns of change after spring floods was studied for primary production, nutrient retention, and community composition (of invertebrates and plants). A shift in the macroinvertebrate community in response to climate change (increasing drought) was evident when data from the 10 years of this LTREB project were compared to the long-term record. This research extended a valuable database on stream responses to disturbance from >30 to >40 years.

Broader Impacts: An interdisciplinary team of > 20 collaborators is reevaluating stream ecosystem models and testing new models using long-term data from this and other desert streams. The Collaborative for Research in Aridland Stream Systems (CRASS) has been established and formed four working groups to synthesize long-term data on aridland streams, led by early career researchers (two graduate students and two postdocs). This project has trained six graduate students (including one Fulbright scholar), 13 undergraduate students (including five REU), and four technicians in field methods in stream ecology, data synthesis and modeling, and analytical laboratory methods. The research has contributed to five dissertations (three in progress) and two Masters theses, and has resulted in eight journal publications in print or in progress, seven conference presentations, and eight published datasets.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2021
Modified by: Nancy B Grimm
